title: US urges Pakistan and India to give peace a chance - Pakistan - DAWN.COM
content:
• Rubio calls Shehbaz, Indian foreign minister; supports ‘direct dialogue’ between arch-rivals
• PM chairs high-level meeting, endorses NSC decisions

ISLAMABAD: As India and Pakistan come to the brink of a full-scale war, the United States on Thursday urged the nuclear-armed neighbours to de-escalate and engage in a direct dialogue to bring down tensions in the region.

State Department Secretary Marco Rubio called Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif and Indian Foreign Minister Subrahmanyam Jaishankar on Thursday and “emphasised the need for immediate de-escalation”, according to a US spokesperson.

In a statement, State Department spokesperson Tammy Bruce said

Mr Rubio expressed support for a direct dialogue between India and Pakistan and encouraged continued efforts to improve communications.

“The secretary expressed sorrow for the reported loss of civilian lives in the current conflict. He reiterated his calls for Pakistan to take concrete steps to end any support for terrorist groups,” Ms Bruce said.

Separately, the Prime Minister’s Office also issued a statement regarding the phone call, saying the premier received a telephone call from US Secretary of State Marco Rubio on Thursday evening.

The US secretary telephoned the PM on the day when US President Donald Trump urged both countries to restrain after what he called a ‘tit-for-tat’ response by Pakistan, it said.

It added that the premier conveyed Pakistan’s strong condemnation of India’s missile and drone strikes that had led to the death of 31 civilians, injured 57 others and damaged civilian infrastructures.

India’s attacks had violated Pakistan’s sovereignty and territorial integrity, while gravely jeopardising peace and stability in the South Asia region, the PM added. He reaffirmed Pakistan’s firm resolve to defend its sovereignty and territorial integrity at all costs.

He noted that the people of Pakistan were outraged by India’s unprovoked acts of war, and stressed that Pakistan reserved the right to act in self-defence, in accordance with Article 51 of the UN Charter.

Prime Minister Shehbaz appreciated President Trump’s concern over the current security situation in South Asia. Secretary Rubio noted that the US was closely following the situation in South Asia as it was committed to promoting peace and stability in the region. To this end, he emphasised the need for Pakistan and India to work closely to de-escalate the situation.

According to the Indian media, the US secretary made similar remarks in his call with Indian foreign minister S. Jaishankar, asking for immediate de-escalation. Secretary Rubio expressed US support for direct dialogue between India and Pakistan and encouraged continued efforts to improve communications. The secretary reiterated his condolences for the horrific terrorist attack in Pahalgam and reaffirmed the United States’ commitment to work with India in the fight against terrorism.

Security meeting

A day after the National Security Committee (NSC) meeting, PM Shehbaz endorsed its decisions during a high-level meeting on Thursday.

A source in the PMO told Dawn that the meeting was attended by Chief of Army Staff Gen Syed Asim Munir, PML-N President Nawaz Sharif, Foreign Minister Ishaq Dar, and senior members of the federal cabinet. The meeting discussed the latest situation emanating from the Indian aggression and was informed that India had launched drone attacks against Pakistan on Thursday.

During the meeting, it was reiterated that India was trying its best to start a war between the two nuclear states without assessing that it could affect the entire world.

The meeting also expressed concern over fake news being spread by India and stressed the need to keep the international media and the world updated about the factual situation and India’s designs.

Published in Dawn, May 9th, 2025
